moments.quote: is, "Will you please tell me how to make somebody else be different?" Oh, I answer, I have a hard time making you be different. Yeah. Much less going through a second person. So, the book really focuses on what do you do about yourself when you have to deal with people you think are difficult and hopefully they don't think you're difficult. Uhhuh. But that's what happens. This is not the lady six houses down the street that you can drive by and just haunt because she's a keragen. This is your mother and you got to get along with your mother. So, what do you do about it?
moments.why_it_hits: Flips the common desire to change others into a hard truth about changing yourself, landing with the punch that the ‘difficult person’ is your own mother.

persona_captions.historian: Modern therapy can’t fix your mom; you must change.
persona_captions.thomist: You can’t control others’ wills, only your own.
persona_captions.ex_protestant: I tried changing people; Christ changed me instead.
persona_captions.meme_catholic: Plot twist: the problem is… you.
persona_captions.old_world_catholic: First convert thyself, then endure thy kin.
persona_captions.catholic: Grace starts with your own conversion, not theirs.

moments.quote: If you challenge it, which is what the shrinks tell you to do, they tell you to be assertive. You know, step up, show your rights. Well, as a Christian, when our Lord said, "Turn the other cheek," what he really meant was, "Don't let somebody insult you. You can slap me on the cheek. It's not going to insult me." So, I think a a good stare is a nice approach.
moments.why_it_hits: Contradicts pop-psych ‘assertiveness’ with a sharp reinterpretation of turning the other cheek that feels bold and countercultural.

persona_captions.historian: Christ’s command isn’t weakness; it’s interior strength.
persona_captions.thomist: Turning the cheek is mastery of passion, not passivity.
persona_captions.ex_protestant: This verse isn’t about being a doormat; it’s freedom.
persona_captions.old_world_catholic: Suffer the slight; guard the soul.
persona_captions.catholic: Real strength is not letting insults own you.

moments.quote: I'm teasing you. H, however, you can't get along with everybody for one simple reason. They don't want to get along with you. I always use this example and I use it in the book. Who was the only okay two sinless people who walked the face of the earth but the one they killed? He was sinless. He didn't hurt anybody unfairly and he killed him. So our Lord himself couldn't get along with everybody.
moments.why_it_hits: Drops a blunt, memorable line that even Jesus couldn’t ‘get along with everybody,’ destroying the fantasy of universal approval.

persona_captions.historian: Even the sinless Christ was hated and killed.
persona_captions.thomist: If Perfect Goodness met hatred, so will we.
persona_captions.ex_protestant: Jesus was perfect—and they still crucified Him.
persona_captions.meme_catholic: If Jesus couldn’t please everyone, you won’t either.
persona_captions.old_world_catholic: The Just One was slain; expect no softer lot.
persona_captions.catholic: Holiness isn’t being liked; it’s being like Christ.

moments.quote: Well, one of the pieces of advice, Bishop, that doesn't work is that you stand up front. you take the front seat because unless you're in the very very front, all the all the little guy is going to see is somebody's backside. So, and plus when he acts up and toddlers are toughest of all because between age one and two, you really can't discipline them. You got to remove him from the scene. You got a long walk down that aisle to get out of that sanctuary with him fussing. And you got 27 pairs of eyes looking at you like, you know, I never let my kid act that way. Why is she letting her kid act that way?
moments.why_it_hits: Every Catholic parent recognizes the shame-walk with a screaming toddler and the judgmental stares, creating instant solidarity and debate.

persona_captions.historian: Every era has the Mass ‘walk of shame.’
persona_captions.thomist: Toddlers lack discipline capacity; removal is rational.
persona_captions.ex_protestant: Yep, Catholic parents do the same pew walk.
persona_captions.meme_catholic: POV: 27 boomers judging your screaming toddler.
persona_captions.old_world_catholic: Endure the aisle of stares; offer it up.
persona_captions.catholic: If they stare at your toddler, keep walking anyway.

moments.quote: I always tell them, sit toward the back. Don't bring the Bible buffet in there. You know, you got these parents that got this whole uh array of caloric goodies to keep their one and a halfyear-old occupied. Keep him somewhat oriented toward the front. Don't let him climb under the pew. Don't let him play peekab-boo with the lady behind him, even though he's so cute. Keep him oriented toward the front.
moments.why_it_hits: He bluntly calls out snack-bribery and pew chaos at Mass with a funny, quotable phrase: “Don’t bring the Bible buffet.”

persona_captions.historian: Snacks replaced silence; he’s pushing back.
persona_captions.thomist: Mass isn’t entertainment; order the child to the altar.
persona_captions.ex_protestant: This isn’t a church picnic; it’s the Mass.
persona_captions.meme_catholic: “Don’t bring the Bible buffet” is wild Catholic dad energy.
persona_captions.old_world_catholic: No buffet, no games—face the altar, little one.
persona_captions.catholic: Mass isn’t snack time; turn your toddler toward Jesus.

moments.quote: The number one question I get is from older parents who say, "My kids have left the faith. They reject it. They neglect it. They suspect it." In the book, I deliberately show them how to take their guilt away when they feel like they're failures about this. I tell people, "My 10 kids are grown. Some going to serve the church. Some of them probably going to serve time."
moments.why_it_hits: He flips crushing Catholic parent guilt with a darkly funny line about his own kids serving the Church or serving time.

persona_captions.historian: Even saints had wayward children; guilt isn’t the Gospel.
persona_captions.thomist: Free will means parents aren’t absolute causes of faith.
persona_captions.ex_protestant: You can be a good parent and still have prodigals.
persona_captions.meme_catholic: “Serve the Church or serve time” is peak Catholic dad.
persona_captions.old_world_catholic: Pray, do your duty, and leave the rest to God.
persona_captions.catholic: Your child’s sins aren’t proof you failed as a parent.
